verses.text: After these events, the cupbearer and the baker of the king of Egypt offended their master, the king of Egypt.
verses.comment: This verse sets the stage for Joseph's interactions with Pharaoh's officials while in prison, showing God's providential arrangement.

verses.text: Pharaoh was angry with his two officers: the chief cupbearer and the chief baker.
verses.comment: God's sovereignty over kings is implied. The roles of these two men would become the context for Joseph's rise.

verses.text: So he put them in custody in the house of the captain of the guard, in the prison, the place where Joseph was confined.
verses.comment: God arranges events so Joseph is placed with men who play a key role in Israel’s future.

verses.text: The captain of the guard assigned Joseph to be with them, and he served them. They stayed in custody for some time.
verses.comment: Joseph acts as a servant even while imprisoned, foreshadowing servanthood as exaltation, a theme seen throughout Scripture (Matt 20:26-28).

verses.text: Both of them—the cupbearer and the baker of the king of Egypt, who were confined in prison—each had a dream, both of them, their dreams on the same night, each has his own meaning.
verses.comment: Dreams play a significant role in the revelatory history of God’s people. Joseph’s dreams and the dreams of others are channels for God’s work.

verses.text: When Joseph came to them in the morning, he saw that they were troubled.
verses.comment: Joseph’s compassion here echoes Christ’s care for the troubled (cf. Matt 9:36).

verses.text: So he asked Pharaoh’s officers who were with him in custody in his master’s house, 'Why do you look so sad today?'
verses.comment: Joseph’s gentle question is a starting point for ministry. Spiritual leaders are attentive to the needs of others.

verses.text: They said to him, 'We have had dreams, and there is no one to interpret them.' Joseph said to them, 'Don’t interpretations belong to God? Please tell them to me.'
verses.comment: Joseph points to God as the ultimate source of wisdom, a sign of humility and true spiritual leadership.

verses.text: The chief cupbearer told his dream to Joseph, and said to him, 'In my dream there was a vine before me,
verses.comment: Vines are used elsewhere as images of blessing and fruitfulness (Ps 80:8), possibly hinting at God’s coming restoration.

verses.text: and on the vine were three branches. As it budded, its blossoms came out, and bunches of ripe grapes appeared.
verses.comment: The image of rapid, fruitful growth is a classic biblical symbol of hope.

verses.text: Pharaoh’s cup was in my hand, and I took the grapes, pressed them into Pharaoh’s cup, and placed the cup in Pharaoh’s hand.”
verses.comment: The restoration of the cupbearer points to serving in royal presence, a theme fulfilled later in Joseph’s own story.

verses.text: Then Joseph said to him, 'This is the interpretation: the three branches are three days.
verses.comment: The number three often carries typological significance throughout Scripture (Matt 12:40).

verses.text: In three days Pharaoh will lift up your head and restore you to your office, and you will put Pharaoh’s cup in his hand as you used to do when you were his cupbearer.
verses.comment: Restoration comes at God’s appointed time. The language of ‘lifting the head’ can also refer to imparting dignity and honor.

verses.text: But remember me when it goes well with you, and please show kindness to me by mentioning me to Pharaoh, and get me out of this house.
verses.comment: Even as a prophet, Joseph is dependent on God's timing and on the human response.

verses.text: For I was indeed stolen out of the land of the Hebrews, and here also I have done nothing that they should put me into the pit."
verses.comment: Joseph’s innocence is a theme echoed in the suffering of Christ, the Innocent One (Isa 53:9).

verses.text: When the chief baker saw that the interpretation was favorable, he said to Joseph, 'I also had a dream: There were three baskets of white bread on my head,
verses.comment: The parallelism in both men’s dreams highlights God’s equal sovereignty over all fates.

verses.text: and in the top basket there were all kinds of baked goods for Pharaoh, but the birds were eating them out of the basket on my head.
verses.comment: The imagery of birds consuming signifies coming judgment, as interpreted through other biblical symbolism (Jer 7:33).

verses.text: Joseph answered, 'This is the interpretation: the three baskets are three days.
verses.comment: Echoes the typological significance of 'three days' found throughout salvation history.

verses.text: Within three days Pharaoh will lift off your head from you, and hang you on a tree, and the birds will eat your flesh from you.'
verses.comment: Judgment and shame are depicted in the imagery of being hanged on a tree (a symbol later used in the New Testament for Christ's death for sinners).

verses.text: On the third day, which was Pharaoh’s birthday, he made a feast for all his servants, and he lifted up the heads of the chief cupbearer and the chief baker among his servants.
verses.comment: Royal birthdays are contexts for divine intervention (see Matt 14:6), here showing a separation of blessing and judgment.

verses.text: He restored the chief cupbearer to his position, and he again put the cup into Pharaoh’s hand.
verses.comment: As prophesied, God's word is fulfilled exactly.

verses.text: But he hanged the chief baker, just as Joseph had interpreted to them.
verses.comment: God’s judgments are just; His predictions through His faithful servants come to pass.

verses.text: Yet the chief cupbearer did not remember Joseph, but forgot him.
verses.comment: Human forgetfulness contrasts with God’s faithfulness; Joseph’s suffering prefigures the pattern of righteous suffering and vindication seen throughout the Bible, preparing for redemption through patience and trust.
